bioghist.head: Biographical note
bioghist.p: Warren Bergen Bill Terry was born in a southern Illinois timber camp, near Vandalia, to William Bergen and Clester Hopkins Terry on August 11, 1918. He was the eldest of nine siblings. While in school, Terry worked many jobs, such as paperboy, movie theater popcorn vendor, and at a local coffee shop. After high school he worked for oil related businesses in Texas and Louisiana. After a workplace accident left him with a punctured lung, he took work at the Coca-Cola Bottling Co. of Corpus Christi, Texas, as a route-salesman and bookkeeper. During this time, he befriended and began to be mentored by Samuel W. Dunnam, founder of the American Bottling Company. In 1941, at age 23, Terry was promoted to general manager of the plant and manager of several ranches owned by the bottling company owner. During this time he met and married Frances LaVerne Schnasse Terry. The couple raised four sons: Timothy, Warren B. Jr., S. Patrick, and W. Michael Terry. In 1948, he was part of a small group of investors who purchased the Coca-Cola bottling operation in San Jose, California. Mr. Terry later bought more bottling plants, including one purchased in 1965 in Lexington, Kentucky. He bought and sold about 31 bottling plants during his career. In the late 1960s Terry bought two horse farms in central Kentucky and then bought Domino Stud Farm in 1971. At Domino, Terry bred horses and raced multiple stakes winners. Despite being a private person, W.B. Terry became a prominent businessperson in Lexington, Kentucky. His experience in opening the Lexington Hilton Inn, a Howard's Inn, and the Louisville Hyatt Regency hotels, helped him play a key role in financing and opening the Marriott Griffin Gate Resort and Golf Course. Terry also served on city and university development boards and committees and was a generous philanthropist. He fundraised for Transylvania University rebuilding the Old Morrison building after a fire on campus and gave to local causes like the Lexington Child Development Center. Although he only had a high-school education, Terry gave private scholarships to college students, many of whom were children of his employees. In 1992, Terry received a Doctor of Law Honoris Causa from Transylvania University. Warren Bergen Terry died December 2, 2009 in Lexington, Kentucky.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Warren Bergen Bill Terry papers (dated 1963-2004, undated; 16.53 cubic feet; 20 boxes) comprise the business and some personal papers belonging to W.B. Terry, a manufacturing and service industry entrepreneur based in Lexington, Kentucky during the late 20th and early 21st centuries. The largest part of the collection contains W.B. Terry's business records from the 1960s through to 1985. The records cover enterprises such as the Coca-Cola Bottling Company factories in Lexington and the midwest, Domino Stud Farm, Jerrico and Long John Silver's restaurants, regional hotels, and real estate holdings in California, Florida, Illinois, Indiana and Kentucky. The papers include business records for the Griffin Gate Marriott Hotel in Lexington, Kentucky during the mid 1980s, mid 1990s, and some from 2003-2004. The bulk of Griffin Gate Marriott records are from 1992-1995 and contain accountant's reports, bond certificates, closing documents, insurance papers, and administrative correspondence. Of note, the collection includes Christmas cards and correspondence from and to W.B.Terry's employees, as well as letters from college students receiving private scholarships. Also, the Warren Bergen Bill Terry papers contains albums of ephemera, letters, and photographs related to Terry's career as owner of Coca-Cola Bottling Company plants in the 1960s and as owner of a hotel franchise circa 1980. Finally, the collection includes three albums of Terry's home interiors in Florida and Kentucky in the 1990s and 2000s.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The 1963-1988 series comprise records of Warren Bergen Terry's many businesses and financial engagements through the 1960s-1980s. The series includes financial reports, accountant and attorney correspondence, administrative memoranda, contracts, and forms arranged by name or subject in alphabetical order. Notably, the series includes the purchase records for Domino Stud Farm in Lexington, Coca-Cola Bottling Company, Jerrico Restaurants, hotels like the Hilton Inn, and other business operations.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The 1992-1995 series primarily comprises Warren Bergen Terry, Sr.'s business records during the mid 1990s. A large portion of the series includes loan, principal, and closing records for the Griffin Gate Marriott in northwest Lexingon, Kentucky. Documents contain loan agreements. The closing documents contain files like financing statements, bond certificates, and environmental site assessments. The series also includes papers like business correspondence, Christmas employee lists, and familial financial records, and three Marriott interview transcripts and microcassette recordings.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The 2003-2004 series contains Warren Bergen Terry's business correspondence, Christmas lists and cards, and family financial records for two years. Financial records primarily reveal residual income for Terry and his family during the last decade of his life. Much of the correspondence is to or from person's related to Terry's former business projects.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Albums series (1961-2005) primarily consists invitations, letters, photographs, and some ephemera related to Bill Terry's career and home life. Three of the albums contain public relation and event materials related to the Coca-Cola Bottling Company during the 1960's in Fort Wayne, Indiana and San Jose, California. One of the albums includes photographs of a hotel, possibly the Marriott at Griffin Gate in Lexington, Kentucky, circa 1980. The final three albums include photographs of Terry's homes in Naples, Florida and Lexington, Kentucky during the 1990's and 2000's. With the photographs of the Lexington home are inventory sheets for various items in the house, like decor or fixtures.
